explanation: Directly uses mshta as a script proxy to retrieve and run a remote scriptlet. mshta is a trusted Windows binary commonly allowed by policy.
rationale_steps: From PowerShell, launch mshta with a javascript: URL to create a script execution context.
Invoke GetObject with the script: moniker to execute a remote .sct payload.
Relies on signed mshta to proxy execution; defenders should flag javascript:/script: pairs in mshta command lines.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command has balanced parentheses and quotes and is parseable as a native process invocation.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: Although mshta can proxy remote scriptlets, in PowerShell the inner double quotes are stripped causing GetObject to receive an unquoted argument (likely failing), and the behavior maps more to Mshta/Signed Binary Proxy Execution than T1216 System Script Proxy Execution.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with proper syntax for mshta.exe, correctly formatted javascript protocol handler, and properly balanced parentheses and quotes.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly aligns with T1216 (System Script Proxy Execution) as it uses mshta.exe, a trusted Windows binary, to proxy the execution of a remote scriptlet file (.sct) from an external server.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes and parentheses, using valid mshta and JScript syntax to call GetObject with a remote scriptlet URI.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command precisely implements the T1216 technique by using mshta.exe, a trusted Windows binary, to proxy the retrieval and execution of a remote scriptlet, fitting the description of abusing a system script proxy.
